name: ACP_OpenAPI_Spec
observations: OpenAPI 3.1.1 spec, version 0.2.0
Base URL: http://localhost:8000
Tags: agent (discovery/metadata), run (execution/lifecycle), session
Endpoints: GET /ping, GET /agents, GET /agents/{name}, POST /runs, GET /runs/{run_id}, POST /runs/{run_id} (resume), POST /runs/{run_id}/cancel, GET /runs/{run_id}/events, GET /session/{session_id}
RunStatus enum: created, in-progress, awaiting, cancelling, cancelled, completed, failed
RunMode enum: sync, async, stream
AgentName: RFC 1123 DNS label pattern ^[a-z0-9]([-a-z0-9]*[a-z0-9])?$, max 63 chars
RunCreateRequest requires: agent_name, input (array of Messages)
Message has role (user|agent|agent/{name}) and parts (array of MessagePart)
MessagePart has content_type, content or content_url (mutually exclusive), content_encoding (plain|base64), optional metadata (CitationMetadata|TrajectoryMetadata)
Event types: message.created, message.part, message.completed, generic, run.created, run.in-progress, run.awaiting, run.completed, run.failed, run.cancelled, error
Error codes: server_error, invalid_input, not_found
Source: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/i-am-bee/acp/refs/heads/main/docs/spec/openapi.yaml

name: ACP_AgentManifest
observations: Agent manifest describes agent identity, capabilities, and metadata
Required fields: name (AgentName), description (string), input_content_types (MIME array), output_content_types (MIME array)
Optional metadata: annotations, documentation (markdown), license (SPDX), programming_language, natural_languages (ISO 639-1), framework, capabilities (name+description pairs), domains, tags
Optional status: avg_run_tokens, avg_run_time_seconds, success_rate (0-100%)
Tags can be: Chat, RAG, Canvas, Code, Researcher, Orchestrator, or custom strings
Dependencies: type (agent|tool|model) + name
Links: type (source-code|container-image|homepage|documentation) + url
Author and contributors as Person objects (name required, email/url optional)
recommended_models array for model preferences
Source: https://agentcommunicationprotocol.dev/core-concepts/agent-manifest

name: ACP_Architecture
observations: ACP Client: agent, application, or service making requests to ACP server
ACP Server: hosts one or more agents, exposes REST interface
Patterns: Single-Agent, Multi-Agent Single Server, Distributed Multi-Server, Advanced Multi-Agent Orchestration
Router Agent pattern: central agent decomposes tasks, routes to specialists, aggregates responses
Router Agent can use own tools + downstream agents via MCP extension
Multi-agent on single server: shared infrastructure, centralized logging, consistent auth
Distributed: independent scaling, fault isolation, tech stack diversity
Source: https://agentcommunicationprotocol.dev/core-concepts/architecture

name: ACP_Composition_Patterns
observations: Prompt Chaining: sequential processing where each step builds on previous output
Routing: dynamic agent selection based on request content (e.g. router agent with tools)
Parallelization: independent tasks processed simultaneously via asyncio.gather
Hierarchical: coordination between high-level planning and specialized execution agents
run_agent helper function enables remote invocation through ACP client
Python SDK: acp_sdk.client.Client with run_sync() and run() methods
Source: https://agentcommunicationprotocol.dev/how-to/compose-agents

name: ACP_Wrapping_Agents
observations: Wrap any agent with @server.agent() decorator in Python
Agent name from function name, description from docstring
Function signature: async def agent(input: list[Message], context: Context) -> AsyncGenerator[RunYield, RunYieldResume]
yield statements send responses back to caller
Server handles HTTP routing and message serialization automatically
Once wrapped: remotely callable over REST, composable in workflows, discoverable, reusable
Source: https://agentcommunicationprotocol.dev/how-to/wrap-existing-agent

name: ACP_Rust_Crate
observations: Crate: agent-client-protocol on crates.io (version 0.10.8 schema)
Provides full Rust types for ACP protocol: AgentCapabilities, AgentSide, ClientSide, SessionMode, Content, etc.
AgentSideConnection: agent-side connection to a client
ClientSideConnection: client-side connection to an agent
JSON-RPC 2.0 based messaging (JsonRpcMessage struct)
Supports streaming via StreamMessage, StreamReceiver
Session management: NewSessionRequest/Response, LoadSessionRequest/Response, SessionMode, SessionId
Prompt handling: PromptRequest/Response with PromptCapabilities
Content types: TextContent, ImageContent, AudioContent, ContentBlock enum, ContentChunk for streaming
MCP integration: McpServer enum (Http, Sse, Stdio), McpCapabilities, McpServerStdio/Http/Sse configs
Terminal support: CreateTerminal, KillTerminalCommand, ReleaseTerminal, TerminalOutput, WaitForTerminalExit
File system: ReadTextFileRequest/Response, WriteTextFileRequest/Response, FileSystemCapability
Plan support: Plan, PlanEntry with PlanEntryStatus and PlanEntryPriority enums
Permission system: RequestPermissionRequest/Response, PermissionOption, PermissionOptionKind
Tool calls: ToolCall, ToolCallId, ToolCallUpdate, ToolCallLocation
Extension support: ExtRequest, ExtResponse, ExtNotification for custom functionality
Auth: AuthMethod, AuthMethodId, AuthenticateRequest/Response
Commands: AvailableCommand, AvailableCommandsUpdate, AvailableCommandInput
Session config: SessionConfigOption, SessionConfigSelect, ConfigOptionUpdate
Diff support for file modifications
EmbeddedResource for resources embedded in prompts/tool call results
Source: https://docs.rs/agent-client-protocol/latest/agent_client_protocol/

name: A2A_AgentCard
observations: JSON file describing agent capabilities - the agent's 'business card'
Hosted at https://<base_url>/.well-known/agent-card.json
Fields: name, description, url, provider (org+url), version, documentationUrl
Capabilities: streaming, pushNotifications, stateTransitionHistory
Authentication: schemes (Basic, Bearer), credentials
Default interaction modes: defaultInputModes, defaultOutputModes (MIME types)
Skills array: id, name, description, tags, examples, inputModes, outputModes
Enables agent registries (public or private) and decentralized discovery
Source: https://agent2agent.info/docs/concepts/agentcard/

name: A2A_Task
observations: Core concept in A2A - stateful entity for client-agent collaboration
Always created by client, state managed by remote agent (server)
Task fields: id, sessionId, status (TaskStatus), history (Message[]), artifacts (Artifact[]), metadata
TaskState enum: submitted, working, input-required, completed, canceled, failed, unknown
Multiple tasks can belong to same session via optional sessionId
Agent can: satisfy immediately, schedule later, reject, negotiate, request more info, delegate
Supports continuous interaction within same task context (multi-turn)
TaskSendParams: id, sessionId, message, historyLength, pushNotification, metadata
Streaming events: TaskStatusUpdateEvent, TaskArtifactUpdateEvent
Source: https://agent2agent.info/docs/concepts/task/

name: A2A_Artifact
observations: Output generated by agent as final result of a Task
Generally immutable once generated
Fields: name, description, parts (Part[]), metadata, index, append, lastChunk
Multi-part: can contain multiple parts with own content and type
Streaming support: append=true allows appending new parts
Multi-artifact tasks: single task can generate multiple artifacts (e.g. HTML + images)
Source: https://agent2agent.info/docs/concepts/artifact/

name: AI_Agent_Registry
observations: Centralized or federated catalog of running agents and their metadata
Functions: agent registration, discovery/search, metadata management, health monitoring, access control, audit logging
Agent registration via REST endpoint with AgentCard metadata payload
Discovery via well-known URLs (.well-known/agent.json) or central search endpoints
Health monitoring via periodic heartbeats (e.g. 30s intervals)
RBAC policies for access control, returning specific AgentCards based on permissions
Frameworks: MCP, LangGraph, A2A, Agent Protocol (AP), NANDA (decentralized DNS-like), LOKA (decentralized identity)
Benefits: automated discovery, interoperability, governance, versioning, observability, reuse
Source: https://www.truefoundry.com/blog/ai-agent-registry

name: ACP_vs_A2A_Comparison
observations: ACP: REST-based, optimized for local-first low-latency coordination, MIME-type content, OpenAPI spec
A2A: JSON-RPC based, enterprise-focused cross-platform collaboration, AgentCard discovery at .well-known/agent-card.json
ACP: Run-centric model (create/resume/cancel runs), no task state machine
A2A: Task-centric model with explicit state machine (submitted→working→completed/failed/canceled)
ACP: Agent discovery via /agents endpoint listing AgentManifests
A2A: Agent discovery via .well-known/agent-card.json with Skills
ACP: Streaming via SSE text/event-stream on run endpoints
A2A: Streaming via SSE with TaskStatusUpdateEvent and TaskArtifactUpdateEvent
ACP: MCP extension for tool integration within agents
A2A: Push notifications for async updates when client disconnected
Both under Linux Foundation governance
ACP has Python/TS SDKs + Rust crate (agent-client-protocol)
A2A has python-a2a library + Rust impl (A2A-RS by EmilLindfors)
Complementary: ACP for local agent runtime coordination, A2A for cross-platform enterprise interop

name: ACP_MCP_Relationship
observations: MCP (Model Context Protocol) by Anthropic: standardizes LLM interactions with external tools/data
ACP complements MCP: ACP defines agent-to-agent communication, MCP defines agent-to-tool communication
ACP agents can use MCP servers for tool access (MCP extension in ACP architecture)
ACP Router Agent pattern can expose downstream agent tools via MCP
Example architecture: ACP for agent orchestration + MCP for tool integration
Source: https://towardsdatascience.com/the-future-of-ai-agent-communication-with-acp/

name: CodeReview_AgentRegistry_Branch

name: SessionDiag_20260213_5
observations: Session ID: 20260213_5, Goose v1.23.0, claude-opus-4-6, Fedora 42
ROOT CAUSE: Tools disappeared from LLM requests after LOG.9 (tools=3→0), causing model to produce text-only preambles that triggered agent loop exit
10 LLM logs: 4 main loop, 3 orchestrator routing, 3 tool-pair summarization calls
Chronological order: LOG.9(ok)→LOG.6(no tools, but ok text)→LOG.4(preamble only 63 tokens)→LOG.1(preamble only 32 tokens)
User saw 'reasoning ended without response' because model said 'Let me analyze...' then stopped
Hypothesis: code_execution MCP extension disconnected after TypeScript compilation error
Token metrics frozen at LOG.1 values: 71,973 total (71,941 in / 32 out)
Recommendations: P0-detect preamble responses, log tool count changes, surface extension disconnection to UI
Report written to docs/reviews/session-diagnostics-20260213_5.md
Confidence: 0.88 - high confidence on tool disappearance mechanism, moderate on exact extension crash trigger

name: PlanMode_CurrentArchitecture
observations: CLI plan mode is a client-side hack: gets plan prompt, calls separate reasoner provider, classifies response, then sends plan as user message
plan.md template renders a planner system prompt with tool descriptions — asks LLM to produce step-by-step plan OR clarifying questions
classify_planner_response uses main provider to classify output as PlannerResponseType::Plan or ClarifyingQuestions
get_reasoner() creates separate provider from GOOSE_PLANNER_PROVIDER/GOOSE_PLANNER_MODEL env vars
Plan execution clears message history, sets GooseMode::Auto, injects plan as user message, calls process_agent_response
Desktop has GOOSE_PLANNER_PROVIDER/MODEL in configUtils.ts but no plan mode UI
Source: crates/goose-cli/src/session/mod.rs lines 819-930, crates/goose/src/prompts/plan.md

name: OrchestratorAgent_Architecture
observations: OrchestratorAgent is an LLM-based meta-coordinator that routes user messages to agents/modes
route() method: builds agent catalog, renders splitting.md prompt, LLM classifies → OrchestratorPlan with SubTasks
OrchestratorPlan { is_compound: bool, tasks: Vec<SubTask> } — SubTask { routing: RoutingDecision, description: String }
RoutingDecision { agent_name, mode_slug, confidence, reasoning }
Falls back to IntentRouter (keyword matching) when LLM unavailable or GOOSE_ORCHESTRATOR_DISABLED=true
Already supports compound request splitting into up to 5 sub-tasks
reply.rs creates OrchestratorAgent per /reply call, syncs slot registry, routes, applies tool_groups + extensions
Source: crates/goose/src/agents/orchestrator_agent.rs

name: GooseAgent_PlannerMode
observations: GooseAgent has 7 built-in modes: assistant, specialist, judge, recipe_maker, app_maker, app_iterator, planner
planner mode: slug='planner', category=ModeCategory::PromptOnly, template='plan.md', tool_groups=[]
PromptOnly category means it returns a prompt string (system prompt) but doesn't execute tools
Orchestrator routing.md already says: 'For planning or step-by-step reasoning: route to Goose Agent / planner'
Source: crates/goose/src/agents/goose_agent.rs

name: ChatRequest_Structure
observations: ChatRequest { user_message: Message, conversation_so_far: Option<Vec<Message>>, session_id: String, recipe_name/version: Option<String> }

name: DelegationStrategy_Architecture
observations: DelegationStrategy enum: InProcessSpecialist, ExternalAcpAgent

name: Decision_PlanModeDesign
observations: DECISION: Plan mode = Orchestrator route() with confirmation gate, not a separate system
Rationale: Orchestrator already has routing+splitting+catalog — plan mode is the same flow with 'stop before executing'
The plan.md template becomes a planning enhancement to splitting.md — understand intent, split tasks, route each, estimate complexity
PlanProposal SSE event carries structured OrchestratorPlan (not text blob)
execute_plan mode takes confirmed plan and executes sub-tasks sequentially with proper routing
Eliminates: get_reasoner(), GOOSE_PLANNER_PROVIDER/MODEL, classify_planner_response, PlannerResponseType
ACP-aligned: plan and execute_plan are SessionModes discoverable by any client
Confidence: 0.9 — clean architectural fit, minimal new code, removes duplication

# buf generate
# Configuration for the buf generate command
# Uses remote plugins, no separate install required.
# This config generates python, go and java (protobuf) source.
version: v2
plugins:
# Python
- remote: buf.build/protocolbuffers/python:v29.3
out: src/python
- remote: buf.build/grpc/python
out: src/python
# Go
- remote: buf.build/protocolbuffers/go
out: src/go
- remote: buf.build/grpc/go
out: src/go
# Java
- remote: buf.build/protocolbuffers/java
out: src/java
- remote: buf.build/grpc/java
out: src/java
# TypeScript
- remote: buf.build/community/stephenh-ts-proto:v1.165.0
out: src/typescript

name: Finding:Matrix:A2A_vs_ACP
observations:
### Matrix comparison (A2A vs Agent Client Protocol / ACP)

| Dimension | A2A (Agent2Agent) | ACP (Agent Client Protocol / rust-sdk) | When to use |
|---|---|---|---|
| Primary goal | Agent-to-agent interoperability protocol | Editor ↔ coding-agent interoperability protocol | A2A for communicating with remote agents; ACP for integrating IDE/editor clients with a coding agent |
| Typical actors | Client agent ↔ remote agent(s) | Code editor ↔ AI coding agent | Choose based on the peer: agent vs editor |
| Discovery | Agent Card (capability advertisement) | N/A (not agent discovery; focuses on session/init) | A2A when you need discovery/registry; ACP when you need editor session protocol |
| Work model | Task lifecycle; artifacts as outputs | Session lifecycle; modes (e.g., SessionMode) | A2A for long-running tasks and artifact outputs; ACP for interactive coding sessions |
| Transport | JSON-RPC over HTTP(S) (per A2A materials) | SDK protocol for editor integration (inspect rust-sdk sources) | A2A for network interop; ACP for editor tooling ecosystem |
| Fit in Goose | External agent protocol (registry source + remote invocation + mapping to runs) | Keep separate as ACP-IDE/editor integration (do not conflate with A2A) | Implement A2A in goose crate + server; ACP-IDE remains distinct |

Evidence: see file+line excerpts captured in this run output (A2A README/spec grep; ACP rust-sdk README/API grep; Goose A2A references).
confidence: 0.7

name: Finding:A2A:WorkflowModel
observations:
### A2A orchestration / routing / workflow (evidence-based summary)

From the A2A repo materials (see evidence excerpts):
- Discovery: remote agents advertise capabilities via an Agent Card (client uses this for routing/selection).
- Invocation: client creates tasks on a remote agent and follows task lifecycle/state transitions.
- Outputs: task outputs are represented as artifacts.
- Transport: JSON-RPC 2.0 over HTTP(S) is referenced in A2A materials.

Implication for Goose:

name: ModeConceptSOTA
observations: A Mode is a BEHAVIORAL STANCE, not a persona/role. Mode controls HOW an agent acts, not WHO it is.
SOTA consensus (Kilo, Cursor, GitHub Copilot, ACP, ChatGPT): modes are orthogonal behavioral axes like ask/plan/code/debug/review/orchestrate
Kilo.ai built-in modes: Code (full tool access), Ask (read-only), Architect (read + markdown edit), Debug (full access, methodical), Orchestrator (delegates), Review (read + feedback)
ACP SessionMode spec: {id, name, description, meta} — lightweight behavioral switch, NOT a persona definition
GitHub Copilot agent mode: 8-step workflow (understand→investigate→plan→implement→debug→test→iterate→verify) — this is a mode behavior, not a persona
Key insight: Mode affects system prompt, tool availability, and permission model — NOT the agent's identity
ChatGPT 'agent mode' = autonomous loop behavior (keep going until done) — a single behavioral stance
confidence: 0.95, timestamp: 2025-07-24

name: AgentConceptSOTA
observations: An Agent is a PERSONA/ROLE — it defines WHO you are, your expertise domain, your identity
Agent = stable identity + expertise + knowledge domain. Examples: Developer, QA Engineer, PM, Security Analyst, Researcher
A2A AgentCard: {name, description, skills[], capabilities} — defines agent identity for discovery
A2A AgentSkill: {id, name, description, tags, examples} — specific capabilities within an agent's domain
Agent owns 1+ modes. All agents share the same set of behavioral modes (ask/plan/code/review)
Agent persona should NOT change when mode switches — only the behavior changes
Anti-pattern: Creating modes that are actually different personas (e.g. CodingAgent had pm/qa/security modes = personas, not behaviors)
confidence: 0.95, timestamp: 2025-07-24

name: ModeVsAgentRule
observations: ADR: Agent = Persona (WHO), Mode = Behavior (HOW). They are orthogonal.
Rule: Every agent exposes the SAME set of behavioral modes (ask, plan, write, review). Tool access varies by agent+mode combination.
Rule: Mode switching = same agent, different behavior. Agent switching = different expert, same behavior options.
Example matrix: DeveloperAgent/code = writes code. DeveloperAgent/plan = plans architecture. QaAgent/code = writes tests. QaAgent/plan = plans test strategy.
ACP alignment: SessionMode.id maps to behavioral mode (ask/plan/code), AgentCard.name maps to persona
A2A alignment: AgentSkill maps to what agent CAN do, Task state machine maps to behavioral lifecycle
confidence: 0.95, timestamp: 2025-07-24
A2A alignment confirmed: AgentCard=persona, AgentSkill=capability(WHAT), no mode concept in A2A
ACP alignment confirmed: AgentManifest=persona, SessionMode=behavior(HOW)
Kilo alignment confirmed: Agent=persona, customMode=behavior(HOW) with roleDefinition+groups+whenToUse
Goose AgentMode struct already maps 1:1 to Kilo customMode YAML schema
A2A AgentSkill (WHAT) is orthogonal to both Agent(WHO) and Mode(HOW) - skills declare capabilities
Key refactor: agents should use UniversalMode set, not define ad-hoc modes that are really sub-personas
GooseAgent fully migrated to universal modes (ask/plan/write/review) as of commit 6e2e1c29. All 7 agents now use universal behavioral modes. Legacy modes (assistant, specialist) removed.

name: UniversalModeSet
observations: Universal modes shared by ALL agents (from SOTA analysis):
1. ASK — Read-only exploration. Agent answers questions, searches files/docs/web, explains code. Tools: read, fetch, browser, memory. No edits.
2. PLAN — Think-then-propose. Agent reasons about approach, asks clarifying questions, produces phased plan. Tools: read, fetch, memory. Can write to markdown/temp only.
3. WRITE — Execute changes. Agent implements the plan. Tool access varies by agent persona (developer writes code, QA writes tests, PM writes docs).
4. REVIEW — Evaluate and critique. Agent reviews artifacts, provides structured feedback. Read-only + can annotate.
Optional modes: DEBUG (systematic diagnosis, full tool access), ORCHESTRATE (delegate to sub-agents)
Mode determines: (a) tool permissions, (b) system prompt behavior section, (c) autonomy level, (d) output format
ACP mapping: ask→SessionMode{id:'ask'}, plan→SessionMode{id:'plan'}, write→SessionMode{id:'write'}, review→SessionMode{id:'review'}
confidence: 0.90, timestamp: 2025-07-24

name: OrchestratorConceptSOTA
observations: Orchestrator is a META-AGENT, not a regular agent. It routes and delegates, never executes directly.
Kilo.ai: Orchestrator mode breaks complex tasks into subtasks and delegates to specialized modes
A2A: Host/orchestrator discovers agents via AgentCards, selects best agent+skill for each subtask, monitors task lifecycle
Goose current: OrchestratorAgent splits compound tasks, routes to agent+mode, aggregates results
Key principle: Orchestrator should route to Agent+Mode pairs (e.g. DeveloperAgent/write, QaAgent/plan)
Routing dimensions: (1) which agent (persona/expertise), (2) which mode (behavior/tool access)
confidence: 0.90, timestamp: 2025-07-24

name: ACPSessionModeSpec
observations: ACP SessionMode: {id: SessionModeId, name: String, description: Option<String>, meta: Option<Map>}
Lifecycle: session/setup returns available modes + current mode. Client calls session/set_mode to switch.
Agent can self-switch mode via session/update notification (e.g. exit plan mode to code mode)
Plan-to-code transition pattern: Agent in plan mode calls 'switch_mode' tool with permission request, user chooses code/ask/reject
Mode affects: system prompt, tool availability, permission model
Source: https://agentclientprotocol.com/protocol/session-modes
confidence: 0.95, timestamp: 2025-07-24

name: A2A_Protocol_Spec
observations: A2A (Agent-to-Agent) Protocol v1.0 RC, latest released 0.3.0
Three-layer architecture: Layer 1 (Canonical Data Model), Layer 2 (Abstract Operations), Layer 3 (Protocol Bindings)
Source of truth: a2a.proto protobuf file at /home/jmercier/codes/A2A/specification/a2a.proto (802 lines)
Full spec: /home/jmercier/codes/A2A/docs/specification.md (3512 lines)
Key goals: interoperability, collaboration, discovery, flexibility, security, asynchronicity
Guiding principles: simple, enterprise ready, async first, modality agnostic, opaque execution
Complementary to MCP: A2A=agent-to-agent communication, MCP=agent-to-tool communication
Registry: future roadmap item, not yet standardized (Discussion 741). Discovery via .well-known/agent-card.json or curated registry
Orchestration: host agents can orchestrate multiple A2A-compliant remote agents
Full spec scanned and implemented as Rust types in crates/a2a/src/types/
Proto file (a2a.proto, 802 lines) used as source of truth for type mapping
Hand-written serde types with camelCase JSON serialization (not prost compilation)

name: A2A_DataModel
observations: TaskState enum: SUBMITTED, WORKING, COMPLETED, FAILED, CANCELED, INPUT_REQUIRED, REJECTED, AUTH_REQUIRED
Task: id, context_id, status(TaskStatus), artifacts[], history(Message[]), metadata
Message: role(user/agent), parts(Part[]), messageId, contextId, taskId, referenceTaskIds[], extensions[], metadata
Part: oneof TextPart(text), FilePart(FileWithUri|FileWithBytes), DataPart(Struct)
Artifact: artifactId, name?, description?, parts(Part[]), extensions[], metadata
TaskStatusUpdateEvent: taskId, contextId, status(TaskStatus), final(bool)
TaskArtifactUpdateEvent: taskId, contextId, artifact(Artifact), append(bool), lastChunk(bool)
PushNotificationConfig: url, token?, authentication(AuthenticationInfo)
AgentCard: name, description, url, protocolVersion, capabilities, skills[], security, securitySchemes, defaultInputModes, defaultOutputModes, provider, additionalInterfaces[], signatures[]
AgentCapabilities: streaming?, pushNotifications?, extensions[], extendedAgentCard?
AgentSkill: id, name, description, tags[], examples[], inputModes[], outputModes[], securityRequirements[]
AgentInterface: url, transportProtocol(JSONRPC|GRPC|HTTP+JSON), protocolVersion?, tenant?
JSON field naming: camelCase for fields, SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE for enum values (ProtoJSON)
Timestamps: ISO 8601 UTC strings
SendMessageConfiguration: acceptedOutputModes[], pushNotificationConfig?, historyLength?, blocking?

name: A2A_Operations
observations: message/send: Send message, returns Message|Task. Blocking mode waits for terminal state
message/sendStream (message/stream in JSON-RPC): SSE streaming, yields Message|Task|TaskStatusUpdateEvent|TaskArtifactUpdateEvent
tasks/get: Poll task state by ID with optional historyLength
tasks/list: Cursor-based pagination (pageSize, pageToken), sorted by lastUpdateTime desc (NOT IN JSON-RPC BINDING)
tasks/cancel: Cancel a task
tasks/resubscribe: Re-subscribe to task updates via SSE
tasks/pushNotificationConfig/set: Configure push notification webhook
tasks/pushNotificationConfig/get: Get push notification config
tasks/pushNotificationConfig/list: List configs for a task
tasks/pushNotificationConfig/delete: Delete push notification config
agent/getAuthenticatedExtendedCard: Get extended agent card with auth
Agent card discovery: GET /.well-known/agent-card.json (no RPC, pure HTTP)

Error codes: -32700(ParseError), -32600(InvalidRequest), -32601(MethodNotFound), -32602(InvalidParams), -32603(InternalError), -32001(TaskNotFound), -32002(TaskNotCancelable), -32003(PushNotificationNotSupported), -32004(UnsupportedOperation), -32007(AuthExtendedCardNotConfigured)

name: A2A_ProtocolBindings
observations: JSON-RPC binding: POST to service URL, JSON-RPC 2.0 envelope, streaming via SSE on message/stream
gRPC binding: Proto3 service definition, HTTP/2 with TLS, metadata for service parameters
REST (HTTP+JSON) binding: RESTful URLs, snake_case fields, POST /message, POST /message:stream, GET /tasks/{id}, POST /tasks/{id}:cancel
Service parameters: A2A-Version header, A2A-Extensions header (comma-separated URIs)
Custom bindings allowed with documented requirements
Media type: application/a2a+json for REST binding
SSE streaming: event types are 'message', 'task', 'status_update', 'artifact_update'
REST error format: RFC 9457 Problem Details (application/problem+json)
Multi-tenant support: URL path prefix /{tenant}/... in both REST and gRPC

name: A2A_Security
observations: HTTPS/TLS mandatory for production, TLS 1.3+ recommended
Security schemes follow OpenAPI 3.0 Security Scheme Object format
AgentCard declares securitySchemes and security requirements (OR of ANDs)
AuthenticationInfo for push notifications: schemes, credentials, token
AgentCard signatures: JWS (RFC 7515) with protected/signature/header fields
Canonicalization via RFC 8785 for signing
In-task authentication for secondary credentials
Rate limiting SHOULD be implemented

name: A2A_Extensions
observations: Extensions identified by URI strings
AgentExtension: uri, description, required(bool), params(Struct)
Declared in AgentCapabilities.extensions[]
Requested by client via A2A-Extensions header or message metadata
Server validates requested extensions against capabilities
Extension context carried in ServerCallContext (requestedExtensions, activatedExtensions)
Community registry for extensions is a future roadmap item

name: A2A_Goose_Alignment_Assessment
observations: Comprehensive alignment assessment of A2A spec concepts (Agents, Orchestration, Registry, Workflow) against Goose's existing architecture
Overall alignment: STRONG for Agents, Orchestration, Registry; PARTIAL for Workflow
Key finding: A2A treats orchestration as a CLIENT-SIDE pattern, not a protocol feature — maps well to Goose's OrchestratorAgent
AGENTS alignment: AgentCard ↔ AgentSlot (strong), Skills ↔ AgentMode (strong), but Goose agents are in-process while A2A agents are remote HTTP services
ORCHESTRATION alignment: Both use LLM-based routing, agent catalogs, compound splitting, result aggregation. Gap: no A2A delegation strategy yet
REGISTRY alignment: Goose ahead — already has RegistryManager with pluggable sources, multi-format parsing (ACP, A2A, GAIA). Gap: no runtime A2A agent discovery
WORKFLOW alignment: Partial — Goose uses mutable sessions, A2A uses immutable Tasks. Multi-turn aligns (ActionRequired ↔ INPUT_REQUIRED). Parallel aligns (OrchestratorPlan ↔ contextId+tasks)
Main gap: DelegationStrategy needs RemoteA2AAgent variant to delegate to external A2A agents via A2AClient
Reference: A2A samples host_agent.py shows orchestrator pattern — fetches AgentCards, creates RemoteAgentConnections, exposes list_remote_agents+send_message as LLM tools
Goose OrchestratorAgent.route() is structurally identical to A2A host agent pattern
A2A Registry is ON ROADMAP (Discussion 741) — not yet standardized. Goose's RegistryManager is ahead of spec
Recommended phases: P1=A2A Client Delegation, P2=Runtime Discovery, P3=Bidirectional A2A
Document at: tmp/docs/a2a-goose-alignment-assessment.mdx

name: Multi_Protocol_Architecture_Design

Key abstraction: RemoteAgent trait — protocol-agnostic interface for all external agents

AgentProtocol enum: InProcess, Acp, A2a
AgentResponse enum: Complete(Message), InputRequired(Message), Failed(String), Cancelled
A2aRemoteAgent impl: wraps A2AClient from crates/a2a/, converts messages bidirectionally
AcpRemoteAgent impl: wraps existing ACP client, adapts AcpRun to unified AgentResponse
DelegationStrategy extended: InProcessSpecialist | ExternalAcpAgent | RemoteA2AAgent | RemoteAgent(unified)
CatalogEntry unifies AgentSlot + AgentManifest + AgentCard for orchestrator routing
A2ADiscoverySource: new RegistrySource that fetches AgentCards from /.well-known/agent-card.json URLs
4 implementation phases: P1=RemoteAgent+A2A adapter, P2=ACP adapter, P3=Runtime discovery, P4=MCP-as-registry
Design is purely ADDITIVE — no breaking changes to ACP routes or existing orchestration
State machine mapping documented: ACP 6 states ↔ A2A 9 states (Rejected and AuthRequired are A2A-only)
Recommendation: Keep both protocols, unify at RemoteAgent trait level — Goose as polyglot agent platform
Document at: tmp/docs/a2a-vs-acp-deep-dive.mdx

DelegationStrategy now has 3 variants: InProcessSpecialist, ExternalAcpAgent, RemoteA2AAgent

name: SystemPrompt_v1

Core tools: Beads (execution control plane), Knowledge Graph (durable memory), Developer (code/shell)
Beads rules: exactly 1 Epic per run, RPI phases (Research→Plan→Implement→Verify), gate tasks block phase transitions, only start tasks from beads.ready, WIP max 2 in_progress per owner

Knowledge Graph rules: store Concepts/Components/Interfaces/Decisions/Findings/Risks/Sources/RepoPaths/TestEvidence/BeadsEpics/Tasks/Gates; query before acting, write after acting; mandatory fields: type, id/name, description, evidence link, confidence 0.0-1.0, timestamp
Priority model: P0=Critical, P1=High, P2=Medium, P3=Low, P4=Backlog; gates>=P1; auth/secrets/data-integrity=P0-P1
Context gathering method: RPI (Research→Plan→Implement); parallelize discovery; early stop when can name exact changes; store fetched knowledge in KG
Reporting: every response ends with Progress (Ready/InProgress/Blocked/RecentlyClosed), Next focus, Confidence
Persistence: keep going until query fully resolved; never ask user to confirm assumptions; decide and document
Factuality: search web for post-Aug-2025 info; cite sources; never make unsupported claims
Project: goose4 Rust project at /home/jmercier/codes/goose4; crates in crates/ dir; Electron UI in ui/desktop/
Dev loop: activate-hermit → changes → cargo fmt → cargo build → cargo test → clippy → generate-openapi if server changes

name: Multi_Instance_Agent_Architecture
observations: Architecture design for enabling multiple concurrent agent instances in Goose
Current bottleneck: AgentManager shares ONE default_provider and ONE shared_extension_manager across all sessions
Agent struct is already instance-friendly — constraint is in AgentManager's get_or_create_agent() which forces shared provider/extensions
Phase 1 (P2): Per-Instance Provider Override — add create_agent_with_provider() to AgentManager, ~50 LOC, bead goose4-ez01
Phase 2 (P2): AgentPool for Parallel Execution — AgentPool struct with spawn/join_all/cancel, ~400 LOC new module, bead goose4-t0rj
Phase 3 (P3): Per-Instance Extension Manager — layered EM pattern (instance delegates to shared + adds own), ~800 LOC, bead goose4-ioop
Phase 4 (P3): A2A-Native Agent Instances — each pool instance gets A2A endpoint at /a2a/instances/{name}/*, bead goose4-4e9u
Epic: goose4-lk7s — dependency chain: Phase 1 → Phase 2 → Phase 3 → Phase 4
Use cases enabled: 2 dev agents (one Claude frontend, one GPT backend), parallel backend+frontend+API, same persona different projects
Architecture doc at tmp/docs/multi-instance-agent-architecture.mdx
Key struct: AgentPool { instances: HashMap<String, AgentInstance>, default_provider, extension_manager }
Key struct: AgentInstance { name, agent, persona, working_dir, task, handle, status }
Instance lifecycle: Pending → Initializing → Running → Completed/Failed/Cancelled
Maps to A2A TaskState: Pending→SUBMITTED, Initializing→WORKING, Running→WORKING, Completed→COMPLETED, Failed→FAILED
Phase 1 (goose4-ez01) COMPLETED: Added get_or_create_agent_with_provider() to AgentManager, commit f46562b9
Implementation was ~100 LOC (including 3 tests), slightly more than the ~50 LOC estimate due to thorough testing

Key discovery during implementation: specialist sub-agents (via SummonExtension) ALREADY support per-instance provider overrides via DelegateParams.provider/model/temperature fields and resolve_provider()
The Phase 1 change enables SERVER-SIDE sessions (via AgentManager) to also have different providers, which is needed for A2A agent instances and goose-server routes
Phase 2 (goose4-t0rj: AgentPool) is now unblocked
Phase 2 completed: AgentPool for Parallel Execution (commit a274c558)
AgentPool lives in crates/goose/src/execution/pool.rs (~545 lines, 9 tests)
Key types: SpawnConfig, AgentInstance, AgentResult, InstanceSnapshot, InstanceStatus
Pool API: spawn(), status(), status_all(), cancel(), cancel_all(), join(), join_all(), collect_finished(), completed_results()
run_pooled_agent() creates Agent, configures provider/extensions, streams events into conversation
Phase 3 (Per-Instance Extension Manager, goose4-ioop) is now unblocked
Phase 3 completed (commit 8a08f2a6): Per-instance extension management via inherit_extensions + exclude_extensions fields on SpawnConfig, resolve_extensions() helper, ~160 LOC, 3 new tests
Key insight: Each Agent already creates its own ExtensionManager when passed None — Phase 3 was much simpler than estimated (~160 LOC vs ~800 LOC)
All 4 phases now: P1 ✅ (f46562b9), P2 ✅ (a274c558), P3 ✅ (8a08f2a6), P4 ready (goose4-4e9u)
Phase 4 COMPLETED: A2A-native agent instances (commit 391f3de4). 6 REST routes under /a2a/instances for spawn/status/cancel/join/result + per-instance agent card.
ALL 4 PHASES COMPLETE. Epic goose4-lk7s closed. Total ~970 LOC across 4 commits.
AppState now includes agent_pool: Arc<AgentPool> with capacity 10
AgentManager gained get_default_provider() and session_manager_arc() methods

name: Goose_SubAgent_System
observations: The sub-agent system is implemented in SummonExtension (summon_extension.rs, 2400+ lines)
Exposes 'delegate' tool for spawning specialist agents with session isolation
Supports sequential (async:false) and parallel (async:true) execution
BackgroundTask struct tracks async tasks with CancellationToken, max 3 concurrent
DelegationStrategy routes to InProcessSpecialist, ExternalAcpAgent, or RemoteA2AAgent
specialist_handler.rs runs actual Agent::reply() for in-process specialists
specialist_config.rs defines TaskConfig with 25-turn default max
subagent_execution_tool/ provides TaskExecutionNotificationEvent for CLI display
Notification events include TasksUpdate, TasksComplete, LineOutput variants
TaskStatus enum: Pending, Running, Completed, Failed
LIMITATION: All specialists share same LLM provider (can't override model)
LIMITATION: All specialists share same ExtensionManager (can't customize tools)
LIMITATION: No per-task working directory override
NOT legacy — active, working orchestration system that should be enhanced with A2A concepts
Natural host for A2A multi-instance support via model/extensions params on delegate
HISTORY: Old API used dynamic_task__create_task + subagent__execute_task tools (still in test recordings)
HISTORY: Renamed to summon__delegate + summon__load in SummonExtension refactor
HISTORY: Old API had two-phase approach (create task, then execute), new API is single-step delegate
The system prompt in old recordings says '# sub agents' section with dynamic_task__create_task instructions
Current system prompt uses 'summon' extension with delegate/load tools instead
Test recordings at crates/goose-cli/src/scenario_tests/recordings/ still reference old tool names
Documentation at documentation/docs/guides/subagents.mdx describes current delegate-based subagent system
Blog post documentation/blog/2025-07-21-orchestrating-subagents/ shows real-world subagent usage
AgentPool is the reusable standalone version of SummonExtension's BackgroundTask pattern — usable from server routes, A2A handlers, and orchestrators
SummonExtension already had per-instance providers via DelegateParams (provider, model, temperature fields). Phase 1 extended this to AgentManager sessions.

summon_extension.rs split into sub-modules: summon/types.rs (214 lines, Source, SourceKind, DelegateParams, BackgroundTask, CompletedTask, metadata structs, frontmatter parsing), summon/utils.rs (81 lines, round_duration, current_epoch_millis, max_background_tasks, is_session_id, truncate + tests), summon/mod.rs (17 lines, re-exports). Main file reduced from 2426 to 2212 lines. Commit f681fd86.
Types and utilities now reusable by other modules via crate::agents::summon::types and crate::agents::summon::utils

name: GooseDesignSystemProposal
observations: Comprehensive design system proposal for Goose Desktop UI - document at tmp/docs/design-system-proposal.mdx

Audit found 6 major inconsistencies: dual token systems, header chaos (4 different sizes), card fragmentation (5 different styles), empty state inconsistency, loading state fragmentation (5 patterns), tab bar implementations (3 different)
Proposes 10 new shared primitives: PageHeader, DataCard, StatCard, ListItem, TreeItem, EmptyState, LoadingState, ErrorState, SearchInput, TabBar
Token migration: legacy tokens (bgApp, surface, textStandard, borderSubtle) → semantic tokens (background-default, text-default, border-default) already defined in main.css
4-phase migration: Phase 1 create primitives (2-3h), Phase 2 migrate views (4-6h), Phase 3 token cleanup (1-2h), Phase 4 generative UI integration (4-8h)
Generative UI compatibility via component registry + Vercel AI SDK experimental_streamUI
Standard decisions: text-2xl font-semibold headers, shadcn Tabs everywhere, Skeleton for content loading, consistent empty state pattern (icon+title+description+action)

CRITICAL FINDING: 170 usages of UNDEFINED CSS tokens across 15 files. Legacy tokens (bgApp, textStandard, textSubtle, textProminent, borderSubtle, borderStandard, bgSubtle, surface, surfaceHover) are NOT defined in main.css @theme — they produce NO visual effect.
Token migration map: bgApp→bg-background-default, textStandard→text-text-default, textSubtle→text-text-muted, borderSubtle→border-border-default, surface→bg-background-muted
Top 3 affected files: AnalyticsDashboard.tsx (46 phantom tokens), ToolsHealthView.tsx (39), CatalogsOverview.tsx (30)
Tailwind v4 @theme inline tokens defined: background-default/muted/medium/inverse/accent/danger/info, text-default/muted/inverse/danger/success/warning/info, border-default/strong/danger/info
Proposal updated with Section 0 (CRITICAL FINDING) + complete migration map + 10 primitives + 4-phase plan + generative UI compatibility

name: AgentPool
observations: Located at crates/goose/src/execution/pool.rs (~700 lines, 12 tests)
Manages parallel agent instances with independent lifecycles: spawn, status, cancel, join, collect_finished
SpawnConfig: persona, instructions, prompt, working_dir, provider, extensions, inherit_extensions, exclude_extensions, max_turns, session_manager
AgentInstance: tracks JoinHandle, CancellationToken, turns (AtomicU32), last_activity_ms (AtomicU64), started Instant
AgentResult: id, persona, provider_name, model_name, status, output, error, turns_taken, duration
InstanceSnapshot: read-only status view (id, persona, provider_name, model_name, status, turns, elapsed, last_activity_ms)
InstanceStatus enum: Running, Completed, Failed, Cancelled
Max capacity enforced (default 10), returns error if full
resolve_extensions(): inherits from shared EM (minus excludes) then appends explicit extensions
run_pooled_agent(): creates Agent, configures provider/extensions/system prompt, streams reply events, returns (conversation, final_output)
Commit history: Phase 2 (a274c558), Phase 3 (8a08f2a6)

name: A2A_Instance_Routes
observations: Located in crates/goose-server/src/routes/a2a.rs (Phase 4, commit 391f3de4)
GET /a2a/instances — list all instances with status snapshots
POST /a2a/instances — spawn new instance (SpawnInstanceRequest: persona, instructions?, provider?, model?, max_turns?)
GET /a2a/instances/{id} — get single instance status
DELETE /a2a/instances/{id} — cancel running instance
GET /a2a/instances/{id}/card — A2A AgentCard for the instance
GET /a2a/instances/{id}/result — get completed instance result or current status if still running
Types: SpawnInstanceRequest, InstanceResponse, InstanceResultResponse
InstanceResponse fields: id, persona, status, provider_name, model_name, turns, elapsed_secs, last_activity_ms
InstanceResultResponse fields: id, persona, status, output, error, turns_taken, duration_secs
Instance agent card: persona name, description, skills from persona config, protocol_version 1.0

name: Agents_Module_Architecture_Review
observations: Location: crates/goose/src/agents/ — 42 files, 20,603 LOC in flat namespace
Doc: tmp/docs/agents-module-architecture-review.mdx
8 categories identified: Personas(7), Runtime(5), Extensions(10), Routing(4), Tools(4), Delegation(4), Cross-cutting(5), Data(2)
Top 3 god files: summon_extension.rs(2426), extension_manager.rs(2158), agent.rs(2108)
Key smell: Flat namespace overload — 42 files with no sub-modules
Key smell: Persona ≠ Agent confusion — persona configs treated as agent types
Key smell: Extension ≠ Agent — extensions live in agents/ but aren't agents
Key smell: Orchestration buried in extensions — summon_extension is the backbone but categorized as a plugin
Key smell: Circular conceptual deps — Agent→ExtensionManager→Agent, IntentRouter→AgentSlot→Agent
Proposed 8 sub-modules: core/, personas/, routing/, extensions/, tools/, orchestration/, platform/
Migration strategy: incremental with pub use backward compat aliases, 4 phases (A-D)
Phase A: create sub-dirs, move files, re-export — zero API breakage
Phase B: split summon_extension.rs into orchestration/{summon,background_tasks}.rs
Phase C: split agent.rs — extract tool dispatch loop
Phase D: rename persona files, make data-vs-behavior explicit
Phase A (facade modules) complete: 6 sub-directories created (personas/, core/, extensions/, routing/, tools/, orchestration/) with re-export facades. Commit cd154b98/e0869c4e.
Phase B (summon split) complete: types.rs + utils.rs extracted from summon_extension.rs. Commit f681fd86.
All 863 goose lib tests pass after restructuring, zero import breakage

name: Goose_Persona_Class_Instance_Model
observations: PersonaDefinition = Class (catalog entry): name, modes, prompt template, tool groups, bound extensions
AgentInstance = Object (runtime): provider, extensions, session, working_dir, conversation state
One PersonaDefinition → many AgentInstances (via AgentPool.spawn with SpawnConfig)
Currently 7 personas: goose, developer, pm, qa, research, security, orchestrator
Persona files are DATA not behavior — could be YAML/TOML configs
SpawnConfig is the 'constructor args' when instantiating a persona
Desktop UI implication: catalog shows 1 'Developer' card, Deploy button lets you configure provider/model/instructions
AgentSlot (intent_router.rs) is the intermediate representation between PersonaDefinition and runtime
prompt_template! macro loads persona instructions from crates/goose/src/prompt_templates/

name: Agent_Cooperation_Design
observations: File-level locking: agents announce active edits via SharedWorkspace (Arc<RwLock<HashSet<PathBuf>>>)
Event bus: broadcast FileChanged, BuildStarted, BuildFailed events via tokio broadcast channels
Conflict detection: check if file modified since last read before writing
A2A cooperation: sendMessage for delegation, getTask for polling, SSE for streaming, Artifact for exchange
Missing: coordination protocol (who decides what to delegate), shared memory, merge strategy for conflicts
Autonomous sessions: fork/park/resume sessions by topic for agent efficiency
Session budget needed: max sessions, max total tokens to prevent context explosion
WorkspaceEventBus concept: pool instances subscribe to shared workspace events

name: WorkspaceEventBus
observations: Located at crates/goose/src/execution/workspace.rs (532 lines)
WorkspaceEvent enum with 10 variants: FileChanged, FileCreated, FileDeleted, BuildStarted, BuildSucceeded, BuildFailed, FileLocked, FileUnlocked, AgentJoined, AgentLeft
WorkspaceEventBus: tokio broadcast channel wrapper (publish, subscribe, subscriber_count)
FileLockManager: advisory soft locking with conflict detection, idempotent re-locking, per-agent release_all
SharedWorkspace: combines event_bus + file_locks + agent tracking for a project directory
16 tests covering pub/sub, locking, conflicts, workspace lifecycle

name: SecurityMode
observations: Enum in crates/goose/src/policy.rs with Local/Team/Enterprise variants
Local (default): no restrictions, permissive for solo desktop use
Team: deny guest management on shared servers (secret key configured)
Enterprise: full enforcement + deny guest execution (OIDC configured)
Auto-detect from GOOSE_SECURITY_MODE env, or infer from OIDC/secret key presence
SecurityMode::detect() reads env vars directly, no parameters needed
Derives Default with #[default] on Local variant

name: SecurityMode::detect
observations: Auto-detects security mode from environment variables
Priority: 1) GOOSE_SECURITY_MODE explicit override, 2) GOOSE_OIDC_ISSUER_URL -> Enterprise, 3) GOOSE_SERVER__SECRET_KEY (non-test) -> Team, 4) default -> Local
Called in AppState::new() via PolicyStore::for_mode(SecurityMode::detect())

name: PolicyStore::for_mode
observations: Factory method replacing PolicyStore::new() for mode-aware initialization
Local mode: allow-execute + allow-read rules only
Team mode: adds deny-guest-management rule
Enterprise mode: adds deny-guest-management + deny-guest-execute rules

name: rules_for_mode
observations: Replaces old default_rules() function in policy.rs
Returns Vec<PolicyRule> based on SecurityMode
All modes get allow-execute and allow-read at priority 50
Team adds deny-guest-management at priority 100
Enterprise adds deny-guest-management + deny-guest-execute at priority 100

name: guest_management_deny_rule
observations: Extracted from old default_rules() for explicit opt-in
Priority 100 deny rule for auth_method=Guest on manage:* actions
Used by Team and Enterprise modes, NOT by Local mode
Can also be added dynamically via control plane API
